docs.lead_paragraph: Naomi Konovitch was unapologetic, barging up to anyone on First Avenue wearing medical scrubs, a clerical collar or an official name tag. To each, she displayed color snapshots of her missing brother-in-law, Andrew Zucker, and pressed on them a photocopied fact sheet. In tidy printing, the sheet meticulously described Mr. Zucker, 27, a new lawyer at the firm of Harris Beach, last seen on Tuesday wearing a gray Izod polo shirt, khaki pants, brown suede Timberland shoes, a Tag Huer watch, a gold wedding band and tzitzit, the fringed undergarment worn by some Orthodox Jews.

headline.main: Hospital Treks, Fliers and the Cry: Have You Seen . . . ?

docs.abstract: Hundreds of people come to hospitals and institutions around New York City, standing in long lines, searching hospital-admissions lists for names of loved ones missing since World Trade Center attack and filing missing-person reports; many come with their own handmade fliers and posters, determined to trek from hospital to hospital, morgue to morgue--searching and hoping; photos (M)

byline.original: By JANE GROSS and JANNY SCOTT

docs.lead_paragraph: Fred Alger founded a mutual fund business the year after John F. Kennedy was assassinated and ran it for more than three decades, through good markets and bad. Six years ago he handed the business over to his younger brother, David, and he has moved to Switzerland. But David Alger, 57, who had been running the firm, Fred Alger Management, from its offices high in 1 World Trade Center, was missing and presumed dead yesterday. So were 37 others among the firm's 235 employees, including research analysts, managers and support staff. So, at the age of 66, Fred Alger must try to piece together what is left of a company that manages $16 billion for individual investors and institutions even as the markets have turned sour.

headline.main: Way Beyond Any Balance Sheet, Traders Deal With Losses of the Most Painful Kind

docs.abstract: Article on thousands of workers in financial services industry who may have perished after World Trade Center towers in Manhattan were rammed by hijacked jetliners and subsequently collapsed; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When the shock and numbness from the attack on the World Trade Center begin to ease, the relatives of the victims are likely to turn to the financial consequences. Suddenly, there will be much less income. Who are the survivors to turn to? How will they get by?

headline.main: Billions of Dollars in Claims Expected, But Compensation Could Vary Widely

docs.abstract: Billions of dollars in claims are expected in wake of destruction of World Trade Center, but compensation can vary widely; amounts can range from few hundred dollars a week for lifetime of surviving spouse under workers' compensation to millons of dollars for executives heavily insured by their companies; compensation can run into millions for survivors willing to endure rigors and anguish of litigation, should lawsuit succeed (M)

byline.original: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER and DAVID CAY JOHNSTON

docs.lead_paragraph: BRET D. SCHUNDLER, former mayor of Jersey City and Republican candidate for governor of New Jersey, wants to give vouchers to parents for private school tuition. It would be easy to pay for them, Mr. Schundler says, because public education bureaucracies are so wasteful. ''Do the math,'' Mr. Schundler, whose term as mayor ended in June, urged in a Kean University speech. In Jersey City, he noted, schools spend about $400 million a year on 33,000 students. Class sizes are about 30. After subtracting money for special needs, buses, buildings, utilities, books, pencils and supplies, ''you've got $260,000 left to pay a teacher -- that's what would happen if we got rid of all that bureaucracy and all those tiers of administration.''

headline.main: Doing the Voucher Math Is Not as Easy as It Seems

docs.abstract: Richard Rothstein's Lessons column says Bret D Schundler, Republican candidate for governor of New Jersey, grossly exaggerates wastefulness of public school bureaucracy in his advocacy of tuition voucher plan; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: They came all morning, all afternoon and well into dusk, an exodus of survivors whose only way out of Manhattan was over the bridges that stretch across the East River. They walked in bewilderment and fear, some doused in ash from head to toe, some wearing surgical masks, some holding a handkerchief or a washcloth over their mouths. Some walked, others ran. Some commanded their fellow citizens to calm down as the first of the two towers collapsed, and then the second, and panic spread on the Brooklyn Bridge.

headline.main: A Battered Retreat On Bridges To the East
headline.kicker: A DAY OF TERROR: THE RIVERS

docs.abstract: Survivors of disaster at World Trade Center make exodus over East River bridges to get out of lower Manhattan; they walk in bewilderment and fear, many covered with ash; the strong try to assist the weak; photo of scene on Queensboro Bridge (M)

headline.main: Goodbye, Dentures: Improved Dental Implants Gaining Favor

docs.abstract: Dental implants grow more popular; number of implant procedures has tripled in last 10 years; about two million implants are done each year; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-10 Tough U.S. Visa Rules Anger Chinese Scholars In a year in which record numbers of Chinese have applied for visas -- and been rejected -- the American Embassy visa section in Beijing has become a focal point of anti-American resentment, its decisions derided as arbitrary and unfair. From the Chinese perspective, the issue is simple: on the basis of interviews lasting under five minutes, tens of thousands of Chinese have found their plans for study, travel or work jettisoned. A1 Pilot Under Investigation Two weeks after engine failure caused a plane's dramatic landing in the Azores, the pilot, copilot and the airline -- a Montreal-based charter company -- are all under investigation about decisions made before and during the drama. One of the questions concerns the captain transferring fuel from the one working engine into the other failing engine. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from two debates yesterday by Democratic candidates for mayor, as recorded by The New York Times. The first, featuring the four major candidates, was broadcast on WNBC, Channel 4, and was moderated by Gabe Pressman. The second debate was administered by the New York City Campaign Finance Board and included five Democratic candidates. It was broadcast on WABC, Channel 7, and was moderated by Diana Williams. Q. Major polls this morning, Mr. Vallone, show that this is a race between Mark Green and Fernando Ferrer. The Daily News says 27 to 26 in favor of Green. Are the polls right or wrong?

headline.main: In Double-Header Debates, the Politics of School Finance and Racism

docs.abstract: Excerpts from two debates by Democratic candidates for mayor of New York; photo (L)
docs.snippet: Following are excerpts from two debates yesterday by Democratic candidates for mayor, as recorded by The New York Times. The first, featuring the four major candidates, was broadcast on WNBC, Channel 4, and was moderated by Gabe Pressman. The second...

docs.lead_paragraph: Peter F. Vallone accused Fernando Ferrer yesterday of running an ''us against them'' campaign for mayor, using the televised stage of the final two Democratic mayoral debates to charge that Mr. Ferrer was ''racially dividing the city'' by campaigning on a theme that New York had become two cities under Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. Mr. Ferrer, the Bronx borough president, stiffened with anger, asserting that his promise to represent the ''other New York'' was an appeal to voters who had not benefited from the economic boom of the past several years. He accused Mr. Vallone of trying to ''inflame divisions'' with his assertion. [Excerpts, Page B4.]

headline.main: VALLONE ASSERTS FERRER'S CAMPAIGN IS POLARIZING CITY

docs.abstract: Peter F Vallone accuses Fernando Ferrer of running divisive campaign for mayor; uses televised stage of final two Democratic mayoral debates to charge him with racially dividing city by campaigning on theme that New York has become two cities under Mayor Rudolph Giuliani; points to Ferrer's endorsement by Sonny Carson, black political organizer who describes himself as anti-white, as evidence that Ferrer's campaign is racially polarizing; Ferrer angrily rejects charges; says his promise to represent 'the other New York' is appeal to voters who have not benefited from economic boom of past several years; accuses Vallone of trying to inflame divisions; photo (M)

docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: Medical malpractice insurance premiums are soaring at the highest rate since the mid-1980's, adding to rising health care costs. Insurers say the increases, typically in the double digits, result mainly from a rise in jury awards, now averaging $3.49 million.

headline.main: Malpractice Rates Are Rising Sharply; Health Costs Follow

docs.abstract: Medical malpractice insurance premiums are soaring at highest rate since mid-1980's, adding to rising health care costs; insurers say increases, typically in double digits, have resulted mainly from rise in jury awards, currently averaging $3.49 million; some of biggest insurers are raising rates in many states more than 30 percent; even insurers owned by doctors and hospitals, which strive to keep rates low, are increasing prices 10 percent to 18 percent; latest increases have put further pressure on doctors' and hospitals' earnings, which have been shrinking under managed care; while doctors and hospitals say they must absorb much of added cost, analysts say they are able to pass some of it on to health care insurers and patients who have traditional medical insurance or pay directly (M)
